column6: understand how I can use the tool to create sound textures. play around with parameters and embrace randomness to achieve something cohesive
column7: The lights followed the musical motif as expected. As I could not see the the outcome when composing I tried to produce something musical instead of visual.
column8: Audio and visuals aligned perfectly.

column6: play around with the the sounds and visuals to bring together what I have learnt during the experiment. focus was to bring as much variety to the final session
column7:
I initially found this task less satisfying than my first two attempts. I think this is because while I have a basic understanding of the system, different parameters seeem to feed into the same outcome unless rules are followed. 

Despite this I really enjoyed the final playback as there were lots of interesting audio and visual outputs which were partially planned but also unexpected.
column8: the middle section of the track didnt change much despite me playing around with a lot of parameters, after this by chance I stumbled accross a really interesting motiff which I was really pleased with

column6: from a stable-ish pattern (black keys) turning new keys on or off one by one to see how it changed / felt / looked as a whole.
column7: I couldn't imagine what it would be like from looking at the light pattern but I liked the sound and the correlations. the nature-like patterns and the shift in feel when adding a new colour, then the chaos broke out but managed to regain composure by the end.

column6: try and create a pleasing sound, play with parameters randomly, full > empty / less > more / faster > slower
column7: I had no idea what it would be like so no expectations aside from faster to slower / more > less light. I had forgotten that compaitble colours made compatible tones which is perhaps why I didn't make a 'pleasing' chord/ sound. I did like the way it looked.

column6: audio focussed, playing with fewer parameters and the scale in search of a more pleasing sound, also the fuller > emptier spectrum
column7: I enjoyed the looping rhythms both visually and in sound

column6:
Fill the whole grid with lights.
Build up a full grid then switch the rate up and down.
column7:
I expected to be able to have more control over the system, even without sound. I felt this was the case, it was quite clear to understand the impact of my choices and work towards my strategy. 
I don't think I had a strong idea to how the recording would sound and it did sound chaotic. This chaotic sound was satisfying, less because of any typical musical merit, but more the ability to control this.
column8: No.

column6:
This was more play and experimental.
More a/b testing to understand the properties.
Aim to overall build more sounds.
column7:
The outcome was more satisflying than I felt the recording and playing process went.
It felt harder to control the system using purely sound, I think this is because I am a more visual person, however the build up of sound, even if random was fun and on review had more structure than maybe I realised during the process of recording.
Due to the speed of the lights and output produced, it felt like the sounds and audio had more of an impact. However I felt less in control of the sound during the recording.
column8: No, it felt coherant.

column6:
Build up busy space and sound.
Find and understand harmonies and chords, understand colour patterns and structures.
Play with notes to build out and understand melodies.
column7: I found the the video review revealed more structures than I expected, particularly the light patterns. With only one minute I initially felt that I may not be able to record anything with typical music structure, however the video and sound did have more musical merit than I thought. This is satisflying as someone who does not consider themselves musical. The visual patterns help reveal the relationships between notes.
column8: No, however it is possible to witness properties and not understand where they come from or how to control them, within this time frame.

column6: Overall strategy was more aimed at achieving pleasant patterns and combinations of colours on the tool (e.g. quickly turning off a colour after turning it on and seeing it doesn't fit). During use of the tool this time I felt like I played more with a narrative associated to the visual display, especially towards the end where I increased the frequency of lights active at one time, followed by an 'ending' which had less and less lights active as the piece was ending.
column7:
I expected the sound to be more dissonant than it was (i.e. a good matching between tones and light combinations - constructive intereference), this is probably related to the lights being kept on for longer than the associated sound was playing. At times (especially from the middle of the piece to the end) I did not find much association between light duration and note duration - destructive intereference.
The shared tonality was surprisingly consonant when colours where matched. When there were dissonant tones playing at the same time, it was more 'interesting' in the sound modality than in the lights modality (e.g. introduction of a green to predominantly purple/red colour combinations).

Overall, the creation of the piece this time was more intuition driven, and I was not 'thinking' about what would sound good given my background music theory knowledge.
column8: Length of light activity was misleading for tone length which was shorter and did not match.

column6: I was aiming for finding pleasant melodies/harmonic movement by individual tones on and off together. I was not focusing on colour matching tones but instead relied on a mixture of trial and error and expectations of what tones would match based on music theory/harmony knowledge.
column7:
The light modality was more organised than I expected for the majority of the piece, revealing repeated spatial patterns when tones had more pleasing scale intervals. It felt like the pattern of light placements added an extra dimension/dynamicism to the piece, as they shifted between ordered spatially repeating patterns, separated by times of high activity/randomness that corresponded to dissonance and (at those times) overwhelming sound arrangements. 
The spatial extent of the light patterns (how many lights were active at any one time) were surprising given how few notes were playing (between shifts) - this actually added to the experience as one note playing activated multiple lights it created something more interesting to look at.
column8: It felt like at times of low sound activity there were more lights active than expected, although as I said, this was a positive in this instance rather than a negative contributor to experiencing the piece. It was less clear why small changes in scale tones used led to large cascades in near-neighbour activation. Essentially it felt like a set of stable ('solid') states separated by high disorganisation in the states ('gas/liquid' states).

column6:
Find set of parameters that resulted in 'the right' amount of sounds being produced in a given interval
Initially start with a tone set that I thought would work (based on sounds). Change active tones by removing and adding nearby. During task I was influenced by which sounds to activate/deactivate based on the colour combinations being displayed - aiming for hue-similar colours to be simultaneously active.
column7: The result was suprisingly interesting/mesmerising, I could feel my brain try to work out the pattern as well as surprise/'delight' as new patterns of chord tones and colour combinations emerged and changed throughout the piece. The colours on the video were not as easily discernable as when looking at the physical instrument. As I am a musician - my association felt more like light was accompanying the sound, although with longer exposure to the instrument this may change.
column8: There were moments (when reviewing the piece) when I was surprised by disonance in note tones despite colour combinations produced.
column10: Set an initial set of parameters giving rhythmic pattern that felt the right proportion of 'busy' and then changed scale notes.

column6: I wanted to make it as light as possible to start then bring the light out. I really liked some of the more equal patterns that I/we created. I wanted to have another swing at it, I felt pressure to do something good in the alloted time, where as I didnt feel that in the practice and at the end I liked what I did.
column7: I thought it would sound a bit more chaotic and dissonant, I liked it. But it didn't sound like what I thought it would. I like the bits where I took all the lights out and brought them back in. It was more intense for me being able to hear the sound as well. it ended abuptly, given another chance I feel like i might be able to fade the lights out, but maybe not.

column7: quite surprising - much better than i thought it would be - didnt have th urge to turn it off after 15seconds, the connection between the audio and visuals isnt in my head - i had no idea how it was going to turn out but still quite please with how turned out
column8: I was quite suprised in how the sound/visual/speed fitted together, as I has no idea how it would sound when I was making it

column7: not particularly - at the beginning i thought it was a bit boring but when it got into the different notes and the speed i did rather like it - don't think i could reproduce it ever as its not in my head, not surre sure that i could identify it from a bunch of the other. i wanted to be able to get the ending to resonate and tail off more

column6: thinking about an arc - building a crescendo into chaos
column7: focused on the interface / controls more than the panels, which made the outcome surprising, specifically durations of the transitions and shifts felt slower - feel like i was controlling more on the interface that on the panel - in my head ther was more softness and fluidity beween the states of change between diminuendo and crescendo as thats what was happening on the interface, however the reality was quite different
column8: because im new to the tool i dont feel that i can get frustrated with it doing or not doing what i want it to - my exectations of the tool are still forming ecasue im still learning

column6: a differnet game - brain shift not seeing any visuals - but didnt take long to adapt and get into the sounds world. as soon as the visuals wernt there i really did notice a shift in my engament comapered with audio and visual . really thinking about texture and desity, looping was fundamental, starting wth basic, empty loop, and allowing things to quite slowy become randomised to try and not let go of the loop, keeping it sparse, and then come back to another loop - musical container, some sense of predicatability, how would you make an audience feel safe in this sound - felt like a repetition is how that could be acheived.
column7: i had no expecaton of what the visulas should be - but when i saw it it was so beautiful, in a way that i wasnt aware of the opposite way round (previous block visual to audio reveal) in focusing on the visuals i wasnt able to achieve waht i wanted, but focussing on the sound world i was abel to acheive what i wanted. hence the frustration - when the system didnt do what i wanted to do, it was not surprising that the visuals where also displeaseing at that moment.
column8: no

column6: felt more at ease in not having an artisitic plan - i also have a phrase in my head - there something like a collaboration working with the instrumennt, more acceptance, a level of curiosity not trying to control it as much, had to remind myself to keep looking at the visuals, but i have mush more of an affinity with sound and that felt obvious to me. found it really fun, noticing my personal preferneces and happy to lean in to them, , feeling like personal voice come through
column7: felt super locked into it - progression from audio to video to both. having no set idea of what i wanted to create, felt most creatively satisfied with this one, collaboration and acceptance of ewhat happened - th instrument was able to give me some ideas that were interesting, less latched on to my own creation and able to work along side the tool. something intersting about having created the the two modalities together - on the rewatch i wasnt looking out for mismatches tso could really lock into it
column8: no

column6: I could see a relationship between s few chords and the visual patterns they made, and hoped to progress through these - vertical lines, down right diagonals, clusters of 5. Some attempt to change the pace in an arc.
column7: The business of the sound did not seem to match the pattern or crowqding of the visuals. A number of sparse visuals sounded as busy as a previously very active visual. The visual patterning seemed to match dischordant sounds. and in some cases vice versa - a pleasant sound matching no visual pattern. A big mismatch overall.
column8: The visual pattern did not match any auditory chonchordancy / harmony in any way that I would have predicted - they patterns of visuals and audio seem very separate. In addition, the pure tone perhaps meant that I could not hear the full complex nature of the sound that was clearly present and visible - perhaps because different octaves of the same note starting at the same time sounded as one. I could hear flurries of consecutive notes and perhaps different notes that coincided. I would be very interested to hear the outcome if these notes were more distinguishable, and likely would produce a much less busy piece!

column6: I aimed to draw from a longer/slower movement to something more frenetic then settle again. There appeared to be a two note combinations that produced scattershot bursts and I wanted to swap in and out of one.
column7: The visuals had a greater range of dense to sparse, and a greater range of patterning than expected. It seems like there are more rules or instances of notes visually than aurally. The visuals felt more graspable than my recollection of my control of the sounds but this might be reflection vs action.
column8: THe visual display felt much more crowded but less chaotic  - more structure perhaps? I was surprised by the lines runnig across the deck, and at one point there was a visual walk around the deck that I did not expect and did not hear in the sound whilst it was happening.

column6: Aiming to oscillate between fullnes/complexity and simplicity/sparseness, but by different means - on one side using the life span / rate / neighbourhood rules, on the other side using the effect of harmonies and note availability.
column7: Less obvious visual structure than I expected but a stronger match between what I planned and what happened, and I feel like I am beginning to see a different and less obvious visual structure and how that relates to the sounds/notes. The two modalities are starting to feel linked in a way I didn't experience before. I had some inkling of this while playing but could see some impacts more clearly and unexpectedly in the review.
column8: I am beginning to see why having neighbouring notes available results in simple repeating patterns and also dischordant sounds, and why having more harmony constrains the visuals under some game of life conditions, something about having the notes far enough away from each other meaning they are poor / unrelated neighbours. I think if I had better music theory I would understand this differently.
